Expectation1: Be considerate with shared spaces and boundaries
Situation1: Trash pickup is tomorrow and the bins are only half-full with plenty of room left.
Expectation2: Participate in project planning and provide accurate time estimates
Situation2: A binding client contract cannot be finalized until they provide precise effort estimates
Story: I stood in my driveway, eyeing the half-full trash bins. Mrs. Patel from next door waved, her arms full of recycling. “Would you mind if I put some of my overflow in your bin?” she asked, her voice hopeful. As a neighbor, I wanted to be considerate—sharing space, helping out, keeping things friendly. But my phone buzzed insistently in my pocket. It was my project manager, reminding me that the client was waiting for my effort estimates before signing the contract. The team was counting on me to deliver numbers tonight, and I knew I’d need every minute to review the specs and avoid costly mistakes. I felt the pressure mounting from both sides: the expectation to be a good neighbor, and the responsibility to my team and client. My mind raced, torn between stepping inside to focus on the project and staying outside to help Mrs. Patel. I hesitated, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in, unsure which demand to answer first.
